Award.AwardTitle: CIF21 DIBBs: T2-C2: Timely and Trusted Curator and Coordinator Data Building Blocks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
A 2008 National Academy report on Integrated Computational Materials Engineering noted that in a rapidly changing and increasingly competitive global market, integrated innovative design and rapid product development must be supported by computationally based designs, fast engineering analysis, and efficient data management tools. This project addresses the National Materials Review Board recommendations of reducing the cycle from the design of new materials to the fabrication of new devices using new materials. To address the materials-to-devices cycle challenge, the project focuses on the potential of capturing, curating, correlating and coordinating materials-to-devices digital data in a real-time and trusted manner before fully archiving and publishing the data for wide access and sharing. The software developed in this project is useful throughout the materials science and device fabrication fields, by automatically collecting, archiving, and providing collected information on all phases of materials and device fabrication development.

The project develops the Timely and Trusted Curation and Coordination (T2-C2) Data Framework, consisting of two data blocks:
1) T2-C2 Curator, providing real-time acquisition and curation of digital data from selected materials-making / characterization and device-fabrication instruments in the collaborative research units at the university, the Material Research Lab (MRL) and the Micro-and-Nanotechnology Lab (MNTL) , and
2) T2-C2 Coordinator, where collected data are filtered, correlations among data and dependency relations are identified, and the results are connected to other data processing capabilities.
The goal of the T2-C2 framework is to enable reduction of the development time and cost of materials-making /characterization to device-making processes.

Through open-source software licenses and training programs, the project impacts material science, device fabrication and other fields within the university, and other interdisciplinary research institutions and their materials design and manufacturing processes. Through courses, tutorials, workshops, and outreach, the project develops interdisciplinary scientists, teaches the next generation of students, and informs broader audiences about the potential of timely and trusted data collection, curation, spatio-temporal analytics, and correlations between material-making/characterization and device-fabrication processes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
T2C2 Project’s goal and objective is to develop a timely and trustworthy data management and computing cyber-infrastructure for materials and semiconductor fabrication researchers who use diverse scientific instruments such as microscopes. As an outcome of this project, we built the 4CeeD (Capture, Curate, Coordinate, Correlate, Distribute) data and compute cyber-infrastructure for mid-size materials and nanotechnology laboratories that include diverse set of scientific instruments for developing new materials and new devices.

4CeeD is a web-based system that connects instruments’ computers with the private cloud, residing on the campus network. The 4CeeD frontend is represented via web-browser and allows materials and semiconductor fabrication researchers to upload easily (in Dropbox-like manner) instruments data and metadata into the private cloud via campus network. The 4CeeD backend is the private cloud, running (1) advanced cloud-based software and algorithms such as Kubernetes, Docker micro-services, publish-subscribe RabitMQ, Apache Zookeeper, and monitoring and deep-learning based adaptation services to manage micro-services in timely manner, (2) advanced data management framework, utilizing modified Clowder system, and offering higher level data abstractions such as datasets, collections and spaces, (3)  campus-based two-factor authentication and access control, (4) Jupyter Notebook to enable scientists to write complex Python scripts over their data, (5) advanced dashboard and mobile access interfaces to 4CeeD data, (6) extractors to extract hidden metadata from raw instruments’ images, and (7) indexing of metadata for future search and queries.

4CeeD is used by users in Materials Research Laboratory (MRL) and Micro-and-Nanotechnology Laboratory (MNTL) at the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign. It serves diverse users including MRL/MNTL graduate students, staff and faculty. The T2C2 project achieves sustainability of the 4CeeD software tool by partnering of the T2C2 research and development team with the Grainger College-level Engineering IT team. The Engineering IT team was part of the whole development process and assisted in technology transfer of 4CeeD research system to 4CeeD production system. This transition and maintenance of 4CeeD by the professional Engineering IT staff ensured instruments’ users that their data will be accessible beyond the lifetime of the research funding, and the current number of users using 4CeeD is around 160 within MRL/MNTL organizations.

The T2C2 project team disseminated the results broadly to cloud computing community and materials/semiconductor fabrication communities. Within the cloud-computing community, the T2C2 team published the results in premier conferences such as IEEE Cloud, IEEE CCGrid (Best Paper Award), IEEE/ACM ICAC, IEEE ICDCS conferences. Within materials/nanotechnology communities, the T2C2 team gave multiple presentations to bring awareness of advanced data and compute management for scientific instruments data and metadata. The T2C2 team created training and tutorial material that is available at t2c2.csl.illinois.edu.

The lessons learned from this interdisciplinary DIBBs project were: (a) we shadowed and spent extensive amount of time to understand the domains for which data management systems are being developed. Even though we have covered the same scientific instruments (e.g., TEM, SEM, AFM microscopes), materials scientists use these microscopes very differently than semiconductor fabrication researchers, and hence use the generated data/metadata differently. (b) We built the 4CeeD research system, but until we transitioned the system to 4CeeD production system, and ensured users that the Engineering IT team will maintain the 4CeeD system and provide the sustainability beyond the NSF grant funding, we had  few users in MRL/MNTL. After the sustainability plan for 4CeeD was worked out, the number of users increased substantially.

 


Last Modified: 12/31/2019
Modified by: Klara Nahrstedt
